intro: Allium carinatum var. flexum, commonly known as the curly leek, is a botanical variant of the leek species characterized by its unique, curled leaves. It is a member of the Amaryllidaceae family and is native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, with its dense, grass-like foliage forming a basal rosette. Its flowers are small, white, and clustered in umbels, and it is often cultivated for its ornamental value and mild, garlic-like flavor. This variety is well-suited for rock gardens and borders, thriving in well-drained soil and full sun.
